abstract.p: Component Retrospective Model Tracing provides two approaches for model-tracing:

p.b: The typical/simple model-tracing approach penalizes learners for all the errors they make in a submission.

ul.li: This approach treats every error as an individual observation with a KC, regardless of whether multiple errors are made within a single submission.
As a result, if a student makes several errors in a single attempt, each error contributes to the total count of observations.
This can inflate the number of observations with KCs, since multiple errors in a single submission are counted separately.

p.b: The retrospective model-tracing approach only penalizes learners for the first error they make in a submission.

ul.li: This method focuses on the first error made in a submission and does not count subsequent errors in the same submission.
It assumes that the first error is the most significant learning moment, and subsequent errors are a consequence of the first.
By penalizing only the first error, the number of observations with KCs is reduced because only the initial mistake is considered a learning opportunity.
